Sher: कोई हाथ भी न मिलाएगा जो गले मिलोगे तपाक से ये नए मिज़ाज का शहर है ज़रा फ़ासले से मिला करो
meaning: In this city of new attitudes, don't rush into hugging someone, because no one will even shake hands with you. Keep a distance and interact cautiously.

Sher: हम हुए तुम हुए कि 'मीर' हुए उस की ज़ुल्फ़ों के सब असीर हुए
meaning: When I became yours and you became mine, then 'Mir' (a great poet) too became captive to the tresses of that beloved. The poet is implying that even a great poet like Mir Taqi Mir would be captivated by the beauty of the beloved.

Sher: ले दे के अपने पास फ़क़त इक नज़र तो है क्यूँ देखें ज़िंदगी को किसी की नज़र से हम
meaning: The poet is saying that we have our own vision/perspective, so why do we see life from someone else's point of view? The sher is encouraging self-reflection and independence of thought, rather than being influenced by others' opinions.

Sher: कैसे आकाश में सूराख़ नहीं हो सकता एक पत्थर तो तबीअ'त से उछालो यारो
meaning: The poet is saying that certain things are impossible to deny or ignore. The phrase 'कैसे आकाश में सूरakh नहीं हो सकता' (how can there be no hole in the sky) is a rhetorical question, implying that it's impossible to ignore the truth. The second part 'एक पत्थर तो तबीअ'त से उछालो' (throw a stone and see for yourself) suggests that if you don't believe something, try it out for yourself and you'll see the truth. The poet is encouraging the listener to take action and experience the truth firsthand, rather than just relying on what others say.

Sher: हम ने माना कि तग़ाफ़ुल न करोगे लेकिन ख़ाक हो जाएँगे हम तुम को ख़बर होते तक
meaning: The speaker is saying that they have given up hope of being recognized or appreciated by someone. They believe that by the time that person realizes their worth, they will be long gone, having left their mark or impression.

Sher: इक लफ़्ज़-ए-मोहब्बत का अदना ये फ़साना है सिमटे तो दिल-ए-आशिक़ फैले तो ज़माना है
meaning: This sher highlights the immense power of a single word of love. If love is confined or shrinks, it will be limited to the heart of the lover, but if it spreads, it can encompass the entire world. The poet is emphasizing the transformative power of love.

Sher: उल्टी हो गईं सब तदबीरें कुछ न दवा ने काम किया देखा इस बीमारी-ए-दिल ने आख़िर काम तमाम किया
meaning: All attempts were reversed, no medicine worked. Finally, this disease of the heart has taken its toll. The sher is saying that despite trying everything, nothing could cure the heartache and in the end, the heart has given up.

Sher: सरफ़रोशी की तमन्ना अब हमारे दिल में है देखना है ज़ोर कितना बाज़ू-ए-क़ातिल में है
meaning: The desire for martyrdom is now in our hearts, let's see how much strength is in the arms of the assassin.

Sher: हज़ारों साल नर्गिस अपनी बे-नूरी पे रोती है बड़ी मुश्किल से होता है चमन में दीदा-वर पैदा
meaning: This sher is a commentary on the fleeting nature of beauty and its rarity. The Narcissus flower, which is know for its beauty, is crying over its own insignificance, implying that even the most beautiful things are not immune to feeling worthless. It's a reminder that it takes a lot for someone or something to truly stand out and be remarkable.

Sher: नाज़ुकी उस के लब की क्या कहिए पंखुड़ी इक गुलाब की सी है
meaning: The tenderness of her lips is like a delicate petal of a rose.

Sher: ग़रज़ कि काट दिए ज़िंदगी के दिन ऐ दोस्त वो तेरी याद में हों या तुझे भुलाने में
meaning: The sher means that whether we spend our life's days in remembering you (or in your memory) or in trying to forget you, it's all futile. The phrase 'गरज़ कि काट दिए' implies that our life's days are being cut short (or are wasted) in either remembering you or trying to forget you, which means that our life is being consumed by you. This sher speaks of the futility of trying to forget or remember someone we love, as our life becomes entwined with theirs, and we can't seem to move on.

Sher: बे-ख़ुदी बे-सबब नहीं 'ग़ालिब' कुछ तो है जिस की पर्दा-दारी है
meaning: The poet Ghalib is saying that his madness or eccentric behavior is not without reason. There is something behind it, something that is hidden from the world, but is guiding his actions.

Sher: मेरे हम-नफ़स मेरे हम-नवा मुझे दोस्त बन के दग़ा न दे मैं हूँ दर्द-ए-इश्क़ से जाँ-ब-लब मुझे ज़िंदगी की दुआ न दे
meaning: This sher is a poignant expression of the pain of love. The poet is saying that their own soul (hum-nafs) and their own ego/self (hum-nava) have become their friends, and yet, they still deceive them. The poet is torn apart by the pain of love (dard-e-ishq) and is barely holding onto their life (jaan-ba-lab). They're asking not to be given the boon of life, implying that life without love is not worth living.

Sher: दिल अभी पूरी तरह टूटा नहीं दोस्तों की मेहरबानी चाहिए
meaning: The poet says that his heart is not fully broken yet, and he still needs the kindness of friends to help him through the pain.

Sher: अब तो जाते हैं बुत-कदे से 'मीर' फिर मिलेंगे अगर ख़ुदा लाया
meaning: The poet, Meer, is saying that he's leaving the temple or a place of worship, indicating a separation or a farewell. But he's hopeful that if it's God's will, they'll reunite again. The sher has a sense of resignation, acceptance, and submission to a higher power.

Sher: तिरे माथे पे ये आँचल बहुत ही ख़ूब है लेकिन तू इस आँचल से इक परचम बना लेती तो अच्छा था
meaning: The veil on your forehead looks very beautiful, but it would have been better if you had used it to make a flag (symbol of freedom/ revolution) instead.

Sher: मकतब-ए-इश्क़ का दस्तूर निराला देखा उस को छुट्टी न मिले जिस को सबक़ याद रहे
Response:
{
"sher": "मकतब-ए-इश्क़ का दस्तूर निराला देखा उस को छुट्टी न मिले जिस को सबक़ याद रहे",
"explanation": "The norms of the school of love are unique. One who hasn't learned the lessons of love can't be exempted, the one who remembers the lessons stays.",
"breakdown": {
"maktab-e-ishq": "school of love",
"dastoor": "norms/rules",
"nirala": "unique/special",
"dekha": "seen/experienced",
"us ko": "to that person",
"chutti": "exemption/holiday",
"na mile": "can't get",
"jis ko": "to whom",
"sabak": "lesson",
"yad rahe": "remembers"
}
}
meaning: The norms of the school of love are unique. One who hasn't learned the lessons of love can't be exempted, the one who remembers the lessons stays.

Sher: ज़िंदगी क्या किसी मुफ़लिस की क़बा है जिस में हर घड़ी दर्द के पैवंद लगे जाते हैं
meaning: This sher compares life to a tomb, where one is constantly experiencing pain and struggles. Just as a tomb is a place where a person is buried, life is a place where one is buried under the weight of their own struggles and pain. The phrase 'दर्द के पैवंद लगे जाते हैं' suggests that every moment, pain is being added to one's life, like threads of a fabric being stitched together.

Sher: घर से मस्जिद है बहुत दूर चलो यूँ कर लें किसी रोते हुए बच्चे को हँसाया जाए
meaning: The speaker is saying that the journey from home to the mosque is far, but let's try to console a crying child in such a way that it starts smiling. This sher is a metaphor, implying that just as a child's tears can be wiped away with love and care, our spiritual journey can also be made easier with patience, perseverance and compassion.

Sher: सरफ़रोशी की तमन्ना अब हमारे दिल में है देखना है ज़ोर कितना बाज़ू-ए-क़ातिल में है
meaning: This sher is saying that we have a strong desire to sacrifice ourselves for the cause, and now it's time to test the strength of our opponent who is trying to kill us. It's a call to bravery and defiance in the face of adversity.

Sher: दिल के फफूले जल उठे सीने के दाग़ से इस घर को आग लग गई घर के चराग़ से
Response:
{
"sher": "दिल के फफूले जल उठे सीने के दाग़ से इस घर को आग लग गई घर के चराग़ से",
"translation": "The flames of the heart's wounds have risen, the embers of the chest's scars have set this house on fire with the lamp of the house itself.",
"explanation": "This sher is a metaphorical expression of the pain and suffering caused by the memories of past heartaches. The 'dil ke phool' (heart's wounds) and 'seene ke daag' (chest's scars) refer to the emotional scars left by past experiences. The 'ghar' (house) symbolizes the person's inner world, and the 'charaag' (lamp) represents the memories that are burning with intensity. The sher suggests that the pain of the past has been reignited, and it's consuming the person from within, destroying their inner peace and happiness."
meaning: This sher is a metaphorical expression of the pain and suffering caused by the memories of past heartaches. The 'dil ke phool' (heart's wounds) and 'seene ke daag' (chest's scars) refer to the emotional scars left by past experiences. The 'ghar' (house) symbolizes the person's inner world.

Sher: हम ने माना कि तग़ाफ़ुल न करोगे लेकिन ख़ाक हो जाएँगे हम तुम को ख़बर होते तक
meaning: We have accepted that you won't remember us, but we will be reduced to dust by the time you get to know. The speaker has resigned to the fact that the beloved won't reciprocate their feelings or remember them, but they know that by the time the beloved realizes their mistake, the speaker will be long gone, reduced to nothing but dust and ashes.

Sher: कभी यक-ब-यक तुम्हें ग़म बी ग़म हो जाता कभी ज़िंदगी तो किसी की ज़िंदगी हो जाती
Response:
{
"sher": "कभी यक-ब-यक तुम्हें ग़म बी ग़म हो जाता कभी ज़िंदगी तो किसी की ज़िंदगी हो जाती",
"explanation": "Sometimes your sorrows merge with someone else's sorrows and become one, and sometimes your life becomes someone else's life.",
"breakdown": {
"कभी": "Sometimes",
"यक-ब-यक": "merge/blend together",
"तुम्हें": "your",
"ग़म": "sorrows",
"बी": "also",
"ग़म": "sorrows",
"हो जाता": "become/merge",
"कभी": "sometimes",
"ज़िंदगी": "life",
"तो": "and",
"किसी की": "someone else's",
"ज़िंदगी": "life",
"हो जाती": "becomes"
}
}
meaning: Sometimes your sorrows merge with someone else's sorrows and become one, and sometimes your life becomes someone else's life.
